markdownRemark.html: All law is universal but about some things it is not impossible to make a universal statement which shall be correct. In those cases, then, in which it is necessary to speak universally, but not possible to do so correctly, the law takes the usual case, though it is not ignorant of possibly of error. When the law speaks universally, then, and a case arises on it which is not covered by the universal statement, then it is right, where the legislator fails us and has erred by over-simplicity, to correct the omission - to say what the legislator himself would have said had he been present. This is the nature of the nature of the equitable, a correction of law where it is defective owning to its universality.
